topic.title: Associating a JSON Schema Through a Validation Scenario

Associate schema through a validation scenario

body.p: uses the rules defined in the detected JSON schema to report errors and warnings during automatic and manual validations that help maintain the structural integrity of your JSON documents. There are several methods that can be used to validate with a JSON schema.

section.title: Configure a Validation Scenario and Specify the JSON Schema
section.p:
You can specify the schema to be used for validation directly in the JSON validation scenario. To associate a JSON schema to a validation scenario to be used whenever the scenario is invoked, follow these steps:
Select the Configure Validation Scenario(s) from the Validation toolbar drop-down menutoolbar, from the Document Validate JSON menu, or from the Validate submenu when invoking the contextual menu on a file in the Project viewNavigator view).
Press the New button to create a new validation scenario or the Edit button to modify an existing one.
Add or configure validation units according to your needs and click the Specify Schema button.
Select the schema to be associated with the validation unit.
Click OK on both dialog boxes.
Result: The JSON schema is now associated with that validation scenario whenever it is invoked.

section.title: Use the Validate with Action to Specify a JSON Schema for Validating the Current Document
section.p:
To validate the current document using a specified schema, follow these steps:
Select the Validation with action from the Validation drop-down menu on the toolbar (or Document Validate JSON menu).
Step Result: The Validate with dialog box is displayed:
Validate with Dialog Box
This dialog box contains the following options:
URL - Allows you to specify or select a URL for the schema. It also keeps a history of the last used schemas. The URL must point to the schema file that can be loaded from the local disk or from a remote server through HTTP(S), FTP(S) or a custom protocol. You can specify the URL by using the text field, the history drop-down, the Insert Editor Variables button, or the browsing actions in the Browse drop-down list.
Schema type - Select JSON for the schema type (other types of schema will not work with JSON documents).
Select the schema to be associated with the manual validation.
Click OK.
Result: The current document is validated using the JSON schema you specified.

section.title: Use the Validate with Schema Action to Specify a JSON Schema for Validating all Selected JSON Documents
section.p:
To validate multiple JSON documents using a specified JSON schema, follow these steps:
Select all the JSON documents you want to validate in the Project view Navigator view.
Invoke the contextual menu (right-click) and select the Validate with Schema action from the Validate submenu.
Step Result: The Validate with dialog box is displayed:
Validate with Dialog Box
This dialog box contains the following options:
URL - Allows you to specify or select a URL for the schema. It also keeps a history of the last used schemas. The URL must point to the schema file that can be loaded from the local disk or from a remote server through HTTP(S), FTP(S) or a custom protocol. You can specify the URL by using the text field, the history drop-down, the Insert Editor Variables button, or the browsing actions in the Browse drop-down list.
Schema type - Select JSON for the schema type (other types of schema will not work with JSON documents).
Select the JSON schema that you want to use to validate all selected JSON documents.
Click OK.
Result: The selected JSON documents are validated using the JSON schema you specified.
